keyTakeAways: Sean Grayson, a 31-year-old Illinois sheriff’s deputy, is on trial for the murder of Sonya Massey, a 36-year-old Black woman, after he shot her in her home on July 6, 2024, following a dispute over a pan of hot water.
Massey, a single mother with a history of mental health struggles, had made three 911 calls in the days prior to her death, with her mother expressing fear that police would harm her.

Body camera footage shows Grayson entering the home, removing a pan from the stove, and responding to Massey’s joking comment by claiming she was going to kill him, which he later wrote in an incident report.
Grayson fired three times, striking Massey once just below the left eye, and was not aware of her prior mental health treatment or 911 calls.

Grayson’s past includes being ejected from the Army for drunk driving with a weapon, two DUI convictions, and poor performance evaluations in previous policing roles, including issues with evidence handling and report writing.

The incident prompted significant public outrage, leading to a change in Illinois law requiring full disclosure of personal and employment background information for all prospective law enforcement officers.
Sangamon County Sheriff Jack Campbell was forced to retire six weeks after the shooting, despite his assertion that Grayson was not disqualified from duty.
The trial was relocated from Springfield to Peoria due to national attention and security concerns, with a jury selected from the Peoria area.
Grayson faces charges of first-degree murder, aggravated battery with a firearm, and official misconduct; if convicted, he could serve 45 years to life in prison.

The case has intensified national conversations about police use of force, especially against Black individuals in their homes, and raised questions about the standards and oversight of law enforcement background checks.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sean Grayson, a Sangamon County sheriff’s deputy, is on trial for the murder of Sonya Massey, a Black woman who was shot in her home on July 6, 2024, after a confrontation over a pan of hot water. Body camera footage shows Grayson entering the home, responding to her comment about the hot water by claiming she meant to kill him, and firing three times. Massey had a history of mental health issues, with multiple 911 calls and prior hospitalization, which Grayson was unaware of. Grayson has a controversial background, including DUIs, Army discharges, and poor performance evaluations in past jobs. The incident prompted widespread public outrage, leading to the passage of new Illinois law requiring full transparency in police hiring backgrounds. The trial was moved to Peoria due to national attention and security concerns. Grayson faces a maximum sentence of 45 years to life and has been fired from the department. The case has reignited national conversations about police use of force, especially against Black individuals in their homes, and the accountability and training of law enforcement officers.
